Graphical abstract Leveraging the excellent conductivity, high hydrophilicity, and tunable structure of MXene, nitrogen atoms are introduced to modulate the local electronic properties of Ti3C2Tx, thereby achieving high-performance VRFB. The sluggish electrochemical catalytic activity of the graphite felt electrodes for anode reaction is still a barrier for achieving high-performance vanadium redox flow battery (VRFB). It is significant to leverage the exceptional conductivity, excellent electrocatalytic activity, and structural tunability of MXene to address this issue. Herein, this work introduces nitrogen atoms to modulate the carbon layer structure of Ti3C2Tx MXene, inducing a reconfiguration of the local electronic structure, which enhances the anode interface activity and thereby improves the performance of VRFB. Ti3C2Tx exhibits high conductivity, excellent hydrophilicity, and a large specific surface area, providing excellent interface characteristics for V3+/V2+ redox reaction. Moreover, interlayer treatment to modulate the mesoporous structure of MXene further increases the reactive surface area. Importantly, doping nitrogen atoms at carbon layer induces lattice distortions in Ti3C2Tx, which enhances the charge transfer processes of the V3+/V2+ redox reaction. The catalysis mechanism is also validated through density functional theory. Furthermore, the modified graphite felt electrode, as the anode of VRFB, relieves a higher energy efficiency of 68% at 250 mA cm−2, while the pristine electrode cannot operate at this current density. In addition, at 150 mA cm−2, the modified battery maintains energy efficiency at 75% without degradation after 500 cycles. This study utilizes rational atomic-level engineering for effective structural modulation to significantly enhance the catalytic activity of electrode reaction, offering a unique perspective for developing high-performance MXene electrocatalysts of VRFB. Keywords Vanadium redox flow battery Anode Ti3C2Tx MXene Structural modulation Lattice distortion 1 Introduction The overexploitation of fossil energy had introduced an irreversible destruction on the ecological environment. To address environmental and energy crisis, it is increasingly important to develop and utilize clean energy, such as wind power, photovoltaic, and water conservancy [1,2]. In order to promote the utilization of renewable energy and meet the flexible regulation needs of power systems, electrochemical energy storage technologies have been developed and deployed [3–6]. Especially, redox flow battery energy storage technologies play a critical role in mitigating the impact of large-scale renewable energy integration on the grid, smoothing out energy fluctuations, and stabilizing power output [7–11]. Of these, the vanadium redox flow battery (VRFB) is well known for its exceptional longevity and safety, indicating great promise for long-term, large-scale energy storage solutions [12]. In VRFB, the V3+/V2+ redox reaction at the negative electrode is a limiting factor for the battery [13,14]. The key reason is that, compared to the VO2+/VO2 + system, the V3+/V2+ system exhibits slower diffusion rate, more complex ligand dissociation, and a pronounced propensity for parasitic hydrogen evolution reaction [15–18]. Furthermore, high-temperature calcination causes highly graphitized carbon fibers, resulting in poor electrochemical catalytic activity and hydrophilicity, which are unfavorable for electrochemical reactions at the solid–liquid interface [19]. Consequently, the V3+/V2+ redox reaction displays slower electrochemical kinetic on graphite felt (GF) electrode. Modifying carbon electrodes to enhance the kinetic of V3+/V2+ redox reaction is a key research focus. The current research primarily focuses on intrinsic treatment and introducing catalysts. Intrinsic treatments such as surface functionalization, doping atoms, and etching for pore formation can improve electrode reaction activity [20–23]. Furthermore, various carbon-based and metal-based catalysts, such as graphene, carbon nanotubes, biomass-derived carbons, Ir, Bi, TiO2, TiC, etc., have been used to enhance the conductivity of GF or provide additional active sites, thereby enhancing the electrochemical performance of battery [24–27]. However, noble metals are unsuitable for VRFB application development due to high cost and relatively low hydrogen evolution potentials. While non-noble metals are low-cost and inhibit hydrogen evolution, their structure inherently lacks controllability. Metal oxides offer advantages such as low cost, good chemical stability, and high hydrogen evolution potentials, the issue of poor conductivity has not been universally addressed with effective methods, remaining a significant constraint on the electrocatalytic activity of metal oxides. Conventional metallic compounds are used in VRFB for their excellent conductivity and stability, but they also face challenges with poor structural tunability. Compared to other metal-based catalysts, MXene materials exhibit high conductivity, good hydrophilicity, large surface area, and strong structural tunability [28]. The transition metal core layers of MXene enable rapid electron transfer at electrodes, achieving extremely high charging rates [29]. Their surface-terminated groups exhibit strong hydrophilicity and provide active sites for charge storage. Additionally, MXene demonstrates excellent structural adaptability and high hydrogen evolution potentials [30]. These characteristics enable MXene materials widely applicable across various fields, including lithium-ion battery, sodium-ion battery, and bromine-based flow battery [31–35]. Additionally, Ti3C2Tx MXene also exhibits catalytic performance in VRFB [36,37]. Based on the characteristic tunability of MXene structures, nitrogen atom doping has become an effective method for modulating MXene structures. This strategy primarily alters the electronic structure of MXene, optimizing its interfacial characteristics and enhancing the binding energy of its surface. Additionally, the introduction of heteroatoms can regulate the electronic structure of Ti atoms, bringing them closer to the Fermi level, thereby strengthening interatomic interactions and improving charge transfer and ion migration rates [38,39]. Consequently, nitrogen doping of Ti3C2Tx MXene can effectively catalyze vanadium redox reactions. There is currently limited research on the excellent catalytic performance of MXene in the VRFB field, and no report has been found on the component regulation and corresponding mechanisms of MXene. Hence, the enormous potential of MXene materials in this field remains to be further explored. Hence, nitrogen atoms were incorporated into the lattice of Ti3C2Tx MXene to prepare highly active composite electrode for efficient anode in VRFB (Fig. 1 a). Based on the material’s inherent features of high conductivity and hydrophilicity, facilitating the charge transfer and ion adsorption during reaction. In addition, nitrogen atoms effectively modulate the lattice and local electronic structure of MXene, inducing lattice distortion and enhancing the activity of the anode redox reaction. The synergistic effects of intrinsic advantages and structural modulation of MXene enhance the VRFB electrochemical performance. Simultaneously, this study clarifies the atomic-level structural regulation mechanism of MXene during the V3+/V2+ redox reaction, laying a solid theoretical foundation for advancing high-performance VRFB electrode materials. 2 Experimental 2.1 Preparation of materials Preparation of Ti3C2Tx: First, 1 g Ti3AlC2 (≥98%, Shanghai McLean BioTech Co., Ltd.) powder was immersed into 10 mL HF (≥40%, Xilong Scientific Co., Ltd.) aqueous solution and stirred at 35 °C for 48 h. Then, it was washed with deionized water and ethanol several times until the pH of the upper solution reached neutrality. Collect the precipitate by centrifugation and dry it in a vacuum drying oven. Preparation of nitrogen doped Ti3C2Tx samples: 0.8 g Ti3C2Tx was added in 10 mL tetrapropylammonium hydroxide (TPAOH, 25%, Shandong Xiya Chemical Co., Ltd.) and stirred at room temperature for 24 h. Then, it was centrifuged and washed several times to remove the residual TPAOH. The intercalated sample was named Ti3C2Tx-TPA. Finally, 0.2 g of Ti3C2Tx-TPA was taken and mixed with ammonium chloride (NH4Cl, 99.8%, Tianjin Beilian Fine Chemical Development Co., Ltd.) in the ratios of 1:15, 1:25, and 1:35, respectively. The mixtures were then milled and calcined in a tube furnace at 500 °C for 3 h with a heating rate of 5 °C min−1 to obtain different nitrogen doped Ti3C2Tx MXene. They were named as Ti3C2Tx-N/l, Ti3C2Tx-N/m, and Ti3C2Tx-N/h, respectively. 2.2 Characterizations The crystalline phase composition was analyzed by X-ray diffractometer (XRD, D8 advance A25, Bruker). The microstructures were observed with a 20 kV scanning electron microscope (SEM, JSM-IT100, JEOL) and a transmission electron microscope (TEM-2100F, JEOL). The elemental composition of the materials was determined with a K-Alpha X-ray photoelectron spectrometer (XPS, Thermo Fisher Scientific). The Raman spectrometer (Horiba Scientific LabRAM HR evolution) was utilized to analyze the structural disorder of the samples. The pore structures of the materials were evaluated by nitrogen adsorption and desorption tests using a 3H-2000PM1 surface area and porosity analyzer. Finally, the surface hydrophilicity of the various materials was examined utilizing a contact angle device (HARKE-SPCA, Beijing Cod Test Equipment Factory). 2.3 Electrochemical test Cyclic voltammetry (CV) and electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) were employed to examine the electrochemical characteristics of MXene catalysts. The electrochemical experiments were performed with a CHI660E workstation. A glassy carbon electrode (GCE) functioned as the working electrode, a saturated calomel electrode was employed as the reference electrode, and a Pt electrode was utilized as the counter electrode. Among them, the working electrode was mainly prepared by the following method: 8 mg of catalyst was added to the catalyst ink in 4 mL of N, N-dimethylformamide (DMF) and dispersed by ultrasonication for 3 h. Subsequently, electrochemical tests were conducted in the solution of 1.6 M V3+ + 3.0 M H2SO4, and the CV curves were obtained from 2th cycle. Modified GF (3 × 3 cm2, Gansu Hao Carbon Fibre Co. Ltd.) was prepared using MXene catalyst as follows: firstly, 10 mg of the catalyst was dispersed in 10 mL of DMF and stirred for 3 h to prepare the catalyst ink. The GF was fully immersed in the catalyst ink for absorption, and then dried. Subsequently, a GF with a size of 1 × 3 cm2 was fixed at the end of a stone grinding rod, exposing a 1 × 1 cm2 area for electrochemical testing. The electrochemical tests were performed in 0.1 M V3+ + 3.0 M H2SO4 solution. EIS measurements were performed over a frequency range from 10−1 to 105 Hz with a polarization potential set at −0.45 V. 2.4 Calculation methods The structure models were constructed using Materials Studio software and density functional theory calculations (DFT) were performed with the Dmol3 module. Dispersion correction was performed using the Grimme DFT-D method to accurately characterize the van der Waals forces between the reactants and the substrate. A special K-point method in the form of Monkhorst-Pack was used to optimize the structure of the constructed supercells using 4 × 4 × 1 k points. A vacuum layer of 15 Å was introduced along the lattice vector (C direction) to avoid non-periodic interactions between atoms. 2.5 Charge and discharge test Charge-discharge tests were conducted with a battery testing system (CT2001A) from Wuhan Land Electronics Co. Ltd, and the voltage range set to 0.8–1.6 V. MXene-modified GF and pristine GF were served as the anode and cathode electrodes of the modified cells compared to the blank cells assembled with pristine GF. The electrolyte comprised 25 mL 0.8 M VO2+ + 0.8 M V3+ + 3.0 M H2SO4. An ion exchange membrane (Nepem-1110) was used to separate the positive and negative electrolytes. 3 Results and discussion The process of synthesizing nitrogen-doped MXene using hydrofluoric acid etching, TPAOH intercalation, and high-temperature calcination is shown in Fig. 1a. First, the synthesized materials were analyzed for crystallographic phase using XRD (Fig. 1b and S1). At 9.51°, a strong diffraction peak corresponding to the (002) crystal plane of Ti3AlC2 is observed, while at 38.72°, the (104) crystal plane represents the Al layer in Ti3AlC2 crystals. After acid etching, it is observed that the (002) crystal plane peak of Ti3C2Tx shifts to the left and the (104) crystal plane disappears, indicating successful etching and increased interlayer spacing [35,40]. Furthermore, after introducing nitrogen atoms, the diffraction angle of the (002) crystal plane continues to decrease (Fig. 1c). This is mainly due to the intercalation introducing large molecular groups and thermal treatment inducing the elimination of certain –F functional groups from the Ti3C2Tx surface. The weakened electrostatic attraction causes molecules to evaporate from the interlayer and decompose at the surface end, pushing the MXene layers outward and increasing the interlayer spacing [41,42]. The alteration of the Ti3C2Tx crystal plane peak resulting from the introduction of nitrogen atoms indicates a change in its lattice structure. This suggests that doping with heteroatoms leads to lattice distortion [43]. In addition, SEM analysis reveals that the etched Ti3C2Tx samples exhibit a distinct layered structure in comparison to the precursor (Fig. 1d and S2). Following the intercalation treatment, the MXene monolayer lamellar structure becomes stacked. Moreover, the subsequent nitrogen-rich doping does not impact the MXene lamellar structure (Fig. S3). TEM result reveals a thinner nanosheet layer structure. Selected area electron diffraction (SAED) map shows clear diffraction rings in the Ti3C2Tx-N/m (002) plane (Fig. 1e) [44]. High-resolution TEM image shows that Ti3C2Tx-N/m has obvious lattice striations and lattice distortions (Fig. 1f), while Ti3C2Tx-N/h shows a larger degree of lattice distortion (Fig. 1g). This is consistent with the XRD results. It has been reported that the lattice distortions can promote redox reactions to some extent [43,45]. Fig. 1h demonstrates the incorporation of N element into MXene. The elemental compositions and chemical states of a series of Ti-based MXene were analyzed using XPS. The XPS spectra of the Ti3C2Tx and Ti3C2Tx-TPA samples display characteristic peaks at 285.0 eV (C 1s), 459.0 eV (Ti 2p), and 531.0 eV (O 1s). It is worth noting that the peaks corresponding to N 1s emerge at 402.0 eV for three doped-treated samples, indicating the successful introduction of nitrogen element (Fig. 2 a). The fitting results of Ti 2p spectra of the five samples are depicted in Fig. 2b, c and S4. The spectral deconvolution of Ti 2p correspond to Ti–C 2p 3/2, Ti2+ 2p 3/2, Ti3+ 2p 3/2, TiO2 2p 3/2, Ti–C 2p 1/2, Ti2+ 2p 1/2, Ti3+ 2p 1/2, and TiO2 2p 1/2, positioned at 454.9, 455.9, 457.3, 459.1, 460.5, 461.3, 462.6, and 464.2 eV, respectively. It can be observed that the Ti3C2Tx-N MXene surface presents partial oxidation. It is due to that nitrogen doping introduces structural defects and alters lattice stability, promoting oxidation reactions [44]. The TiO2 peak areas in the three nitrogen-doped samples are nearly identical. Regarding the C 1s spectra, Fig. 2d, e and S5 depict that all Ti3C2Tx MXene possess five signals at 281.8, 282.9, 284.75, 286.3, and 288.8 eV, corresponding to the Ti–C, Ti–C–Tx, C–C, C–O, and O–C = O, respectively. Fig. S6 shows the O 1s XPS spectrum of Ti3C2Tx MXene series samples. Four clear peaks appear at 529.7, 531.2, 532.0, and 533.7 eV, corresponding to Ti–O, C–Ti–Ox, C–Ti–(OH)x, and H2Oads, respectively. Fig. S7 demonstrates an increasing trend of nitrogen content in Ti3C2Tx-N/l, Ti3C2Tx-N/m, and Ti3C2Tx-N/h catalysts. The spectral deconvolution of N 1s correspond to 397.1, 399.0, 400.0, and 401.5 eV, which correspond to nitride functional groups (N–Ti), pyridinic N, pyrrolic N, and graphitic N [46], respectively (Fig. 2f and S8). The test results indicate that the predominant form of nitrogen is pyrrolic N, which exhibits excellent electron-donating property and high charge mobility. These properties significantly enhance the charge transfer toward redox reaction [47]. Meanwhile, pyridine nitrogen forms an electron pair system and conjugates with a π-conjugated ring, endowing the N-Ti3C2Tx nanosheets with electron-donor properties. In addition, N atoms are not simply weakly physiosorbed on the Ti3C2Tx MXene, rather, they exist as N–Ti. Therefore, the introduction of nitrogen atoms can modify the lattice properties of Ti3C2Tx, regulate the redox reaction active sites, and enhance its reaction activity. [44,48,49]. Furthermore, Raman spectrometer test was used to explore the lattice defect. In Fig. 2g, it is observed that there are two obvious peaks at the positions located at 1350 cm−1 (I D) and 1580 cm−1 (I G). The degree trend of defect for Ti3C2Tx rises as nitrogen doping content increases, which is consistent with TEM results. In addition, the reaction takes place at the interface of the electrode and the aqueous solution. The wettability of electrode is vital in adequate contact between the vanadium ions and the electrode surface, which is even the precondition for redox reaction. The contact angles of the blank graphite blocks, Ti3C2Tx, Ti3C2Tx-TPA, Ti3C2Tx-N/l, Ti3C2Tx-N/m, and Ti3C2Tx-N/h are 108.0°, 53.3°, 53.1°, 43.9°, 43.9°, and 43.2°, respectively (Fig. 2 h and S9). The highly graphitized carbon material exhibits strong hydrophobicity, while the hydrophilicity of the Ti-based MXene is significantly superior to carbon material, due to the presence of terminal groups –O and –OH in Ti3C2Tx MXene series samples (Fig. S6). Furthermore, the polarity of the Ti–N bonds in Ti3C2Tx-N MXene is enhanced and the pyridine nitrogen atoms easily form hydrogen bond [50,51]. These factors collectively contribute to the excellent hydrophilicity of Ti-based MXene. Moreover, the adsorption–desorption isotherms test was conducted to study the surface and pore structure of Ti3C2Tx and Ti3C2Tx-N/m. The analysis results from Fig. 2i show that the specific surface area of Ti3C2Tx, Ti3C2Tx-N/l, Ti3C2Tx-N/m, and Ti3C2Tx-N/h is 2.10 m2 g−1, 3.12 m2 g−1, 6.84 m2 g−1, and 8.74 m2 g−1, respectively. This may be attributed to the expansion of the interlayer spacing, which increases its specific surface area. A larger specific surface area can provide more reaction sites, facilitating the progress of redox reaction. In addition, the Ti3C2Tx-N/m has a maximum accessible pore size of 4 nm, indicating a mesoporous material. The mesoporous structure of Ti3C2Tx-N provides an excellent “support platform”, evenly dispersing and anchoring active substances within the material. Moreover, the pore structure facilitates shorter diffusion paths within the material, thereby enhancing reaction efficiency. CV and EIS tests were used to reveal the catalytic performance of Ti-based MXene electrodes. Fig. 3 a shows the results of the CV test, indicating that all Ti-based MXenes exhibit certain catalytic performance. Compared to Ti3C2Tx, the redox peak current of the Ti3C2Tx-TPA electrode is increased. This is attributed to the larger surface area for reactions resulting from the intercalation-induced layer structure. Interestingly, after the introduction of nitrogen atom, the Ti3C2Tx-N/m exhibits the highest electrochemical activity. This is primarily due to the introduction of larger specific surface area and increased catalytic active sites through electronic regulation after nitrogen doping. However, compared to the Ti3C2Tx-N/m electrode, the Ti3C2Tx-N/h electrode exhibits lower electrochemical performance, indicating that excessive nitrogen doping leads to significant lattice distortion and reduced conductivity in MXene, consequently decreasing its catalytic activity. As a result, the redox current of Ti3C2Tx-N/h decreased compared to Ti3C2Tx-N/m. Additionally, the redox peak potential difference (ΔE p) values of Ti3C2Tx-N series electrodes are smaller, indicating an enhanced reversibility of the redox reaction. The EIS test was used to investigate the electrochemical behavior of vanadium ions on the electrode surface. All the Nyquist curves of these electrodes consist of two parts: a semicircular arc type in the high-frequency region and rays in the low-frequency region (Fig. 3b). This suggests that the reaction is governed by charge transfer and diffusion processes. The Nyquist curves were fitted using a simplified equivalent circuit (Fig. S10) to compare the electrochemical performance of different electrodes more intuitively. The charge transfer resistances of different electrodes in order of magnitude are Ti3C2Tx@N-m < Ti3C2Tx@N-h < Ti3C2Tx@N-l < Ti3C2Tx-TPA < Ti3C2Tx (Table S1), which further demonstrates that the electrochemical kinetics of the nitrogen-doped MXene at the negative electrode is significantly enhanced, with the Ti3C2Tx@N-m electrode exhibiting the fastest charge transfer rate. To investigate the electrochemical stability of the electrodes and the diffusion behavior of active substances on the electrodes, CV tests were carried out on MXene series electrodes with scanning rates ranging from 5 to 25 mV s−1. The results are displayed in Fig. 3c, d and S11. With the increase of the scanning rate, the ΔE p of the CV curve increases, which is attributed to the heightened electrochemical polarization of the electrode reaction. It is noteworthy that nitrogen-doped Ti-based MXene electrodes exhibit the smallest ΔE p, indicating that doping N diminishes the polarization of the anode redox reaction. Among these electrodes, Ti3C2Tx-N/m exhibits the most excellent electrochemical stability. Based on the CV test results, revealing that the anode redox reaction is a quasi-reversible process. All electrodes exhibit a strong linear relationship between the square root of the scan rate and the peak current, indicating that the V3+/V2+ redox reaction is governed by the diffusion process (Fig. 3e, f). Notably, the slope of the Ti3C2Tx-N/m straight line is the steepest, suggesting the highest diffusion rate. The Ti3C2Tx-N/m significantly boosts the mobility of vanadium ions across the electrode surface. Fig. S12 result shows that Ti3C2Tx-N/m has the most excellent electrochemical kinetics. Tafel plots were employed to delve deeper into the electrocatalytic performance of various electrodes. The Tafel slopes of Ti3C2Tx-N are both lower and the redox reaction potentials are lower than those of Ti3C2Tx and Ti3C2Tx-TPA (Fig. 3g). This can be attributed to the more active sites of N-doped Ti-based MXene electrodes, which reduces the polarization of the redox reaction. Subsequently, the SEM images of GF and Ti3C2Tx-N/m@GF show that the surface of pristine GF is smooth, while the presence of nanosheets on the surface of Ti3C2Tx-N/m@GF indicated successful loading (Fig. S13). The specific surface area of GF loaded with MXene catalyst is increased (Fig. S14). To further investigate the Ti3C2Tx-N/m’s impact on the electrochemical performance of GF, the CV and EIS tests were conducted for GF and Ti3C2Tx-N/m@GF electrodes (Fig. 3h, i). Compared to GF, Ti3C2Tx-N/m@GF exhibits superior electrochemical kinetics and reversibility characteristics for V3+/V2+ redox reaction. This is mainly attributed to the introduction of Ti3C2Tx-N/m, which enhances the electrochemical activity of the electrode, accelerates the charge transfer and ion diffusion rate. A detailed study of the vanadium redox reaction mechanism to reveal how nitrogen doping affects the interaction between Ti3C2Tx catalyst and vanadium ion. Firstly, V3+ moves from the solution at the negative electrode to the electrode’s reaction interface, where it adsorbs onto active sites and undergoes charge transfer along Ti-V3+. Subsequently, V3+ gains electrons and converts to V2+, which then leaves the electrode surface and diffuses into the electrolyte. The discharge process is reverse. Through DFT calculations, the mechanism of nitrogen-doped Ti3C2Tx affecting the anode redox reaction at the atomic level and the reasons for boosting the V3+/V2+ oxidation kinetics process have been elucidated, with the structural model shown in Fig. 4 a. The charge density difference analysis in Fig. 4b and c clearly shows the changes in the active sites involved in the reaction with vanadium ions before and after doping. The introduction of nitrogen atoms alters the electronic structure of MXene, inducing a shift in the active sites for interaction with vanadium ions from carbon bridge sites to titanium top sites. The nitrogen element introduced possesses more valence electrons, allowing the Ti atoms in Ti–N to acquire additional electrons from neighboring nitrogen through V–Ti–N hybrid orbitals. These electrons are subsequently relayed to the vanadium atoms, thereby reducing the energy barrier of the V3+/V2+ redox reaction and promoting the charge transfer process in the anodic redox reaction. In addition, after the introduction of nitrogen, the stretching degree at the V–Ti site (3.106 Å) is lower compared to the V–C site (3.943 Å), indicating a stronger adsorption energy. This is consistent with the adsorption energy results shown in Fig. 4d and f. Ti3C2Tx-N has a lower adsorption energy for V3+, indicating that the interaction between V3+ and the electrode is enhanced, and the ion migration rate is accelerated. Fig. 4g, h and S15 show the density of states of the metal d band and non-metal p band on Ti3C2Tx and Ti3C2Tx-N. Compared to Ti3C2Tx (−1.44 V), the d-band center of Ti atoms in Ti3C2Tx-N shifts upwards to −1.36 V, closer to the Fermi level, indicating that the Ti atoms become electron-deficient centers under the synergistic action of N atoms. This is beneficial for electron exchange with V3+ ions, thereby enhancing the activity in electrochemical reactions. Additionally, Ti3C2Tx-N has a smaller d-p bandgap compared to Ti3C2Tx, which can be attributed to the introduction of additional electronic states by nitrogen doping, reducing the energy gap between the bonding and antibonding orbitals of the electrode [52]. This effectively promotes electron transfer between the electrode and electrolyte, accelerates the charge transfer rate, and improves the electrochemical performance of the electrode material. This structural modulation enhances the charge exchange between Ti3C2Tx-N and V3+, resulting in excellent performance in the V3+/V2+ redox reaction. These findings are consistent with the previously mentioned EIS results. To study the impact of Ti3C2Tx-N/m@GF composite electrode on the energy storage capability of VRFB, its stability and cycling performance were assessed (Fig. 5 a). Firstly, the discharge capacity of the Ti3C2Tx-N/m@GF cell is significantly higher than that of the Ti3C2Tx-N/h@GF cell and GF cell, as depicted in Fig. 5b. Moreover, when comparing the voltage efficiency (VE) of the blank cell and modified cells (Fig. 5c), it is found that at 200 mA cm−2, the VE of the Ti3C2Tx-N/m@GF cell is 7.2% higher than that of the GF cell. This indicated that the Ti3C2Tx-N/m@GF electrode facilitates vanadium ion adsorption and accelerates charge transfer, thereby reducing polarization. In Fig. 5d, the coulombic efficiency (CE) of the GF cell is observed to be marginally higher than that of the Ti3C2Tx-N/m@GF cell. This is due to the extended charging and discharging time of the modified cell, which allows for an increase in side reactions and the active material passing through the diaphragm. Furthermore, at 200 mA cm−2, the Ti3C2Tx-N/m@GF cell exhibits an 8.3% improvement in energy efficiency (EE) compared to the GF cell (Fig. 5e). However, the CE, VE, and EE of Ti3C2Tx-N/h@GF cell are lower than those of Ti3C2Tx-N/m@GF cell. This indicates that greater alteration in lattice structure can lead to a certain degree of reduction in the electrochemical performance of VRFB. To further explore the improvement effect of the modified cells on cell polarization, the charge and discharge curves at different current densities were tested in Fig. S16. The result indicates that Ti3C2Tx-N/m@GF has an excellent catalytic effect of reducing the electrochemical polarization. Fig. S17 also demonstrates that the Ti3C2Tx-N/m@GF electrode enhances the cell’s energy density. Furthermore, the cyclic stability of battery was investigated at 150 mA cm−2 over 500 cycles (Figs. S18 and 5f). The modified cell exhibits higher discharge capacity, greater capacity retention, and longer runtime. The GF cell fails to operation after 200 cycles and exhibits significant degradation in EE. In contrast, the Ti3C2Tx-N/m@GF cell completed 500 cycles without any attenuation and maintained an EE of 75%. The comparison of system resistance in Fig. S19 also demonstrates that the electrode has a faster electron transport rate, charge transfer rate, and diffusion rate. The development of Ti3C2Tx-N/m@GF electrodes, which exhibits high catalytic activity and stability for superior VRFB performance, carries considerable scientific significance. 4 Conclusions In summary, introducing nitrogen atoms into Ti3C2Tx leads to the realignment of lattice and local electronic structure, enhancing the catalytic efficiency of VRFB anode. Nitrogen doping induces lattice distortion, which results in higher current density and reduced charge transfer resistance, effectively improving the activity of V3+/V2+ redox reaction. DFT calculations confirm that nitrogen substitution shifts the active sites interacting with vanadium ions from carbon bridge sites to titanium top sites, resulting in higher reactivity and faster charge transfer. Further full-cell performance evaluation shows that at 150 mA cm−2, the EE of Ti3C2Tx-N/m@GF cell is 14% higher than that of the GF cell, achieving the goal of high energy efficiency and long cycle life. This study provides deep insights into the rational design of MXene catalyst for VRFB electrode and establishes a theoretical foundation for MXene application in VRFB. coredata.dc:description: The sluggish electrochemical catalytic activity of the graphite felt electrodes for anode reaction is still a barrier for achieving high-performance vanadium redox flow battery (VRFB). It is significant to leverage the exceptional conductivity, excellent electrocatalytic activity, and structural tunability of MXene to address this issue. Herein, this work introduces nitrogen atoms to modulate the carbon layer structure of Ti3C2Tx MXene, inducing a reconfiguration of the local electronic structure, which enhances the anode interface activity and thereby improves the performance of VRFB. Ti3C2Tx exhibits high conductivity, excellent hydrophilicity, and a large specific surface area, providing excellent interface characteristics for V3+/V2+ redox reaction. Moreover, interlayer treatment to modulate the mesoporous structure of MXene further increases the reactive surface area. Importantly, doping nitrogen atoms at carbon layer induces lattice distortions in Ti3C2Tx, which enhances the charge transfer processes of the V3+/V2+ redox reaction. The catalysis mechanism is also validated through density functional theory. Furthermore, the modified graphite felt electrode, as the anode of VRFB, relieves a higher energy efficiency of 68% at 250 mA cm−2, while the pristine electrode cannot operate at this current density. In addition, at 150 mA cm−2, the modified battery maintains energy efficiency at 75% without degradation after 500 cycles. This study utilizes rational atomic-level engineering for effective structural modulation to significantly enhance the catalytic activity of electrode reaction, offering a unique perspective for developing high-performance MXene electrocatalysts of VRFB.
